facts.text: The 1st Income-tax Officer, C-II Ward, Bombay, served a notice under section 18A(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, calling upon Bhagwandas Kevaldas (assessee) to pay Rs. 25,973-5-0 as advance tax in four equal installments for assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st Income-tax Officer, C-II Ward, Bombay, served a numberice under section 18A 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, calling upon Bhagwandas Kevaldas - who will hereinafter be called the assessee to pay in four equal installments Rs. 25,973-5-0 as advance tax for the assessment year 1948-49.

facts.text: On September 17, 1947, the assessee filed an estimate of his income under section 18A(2) and of the tax payable by him.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17,1947, the assessee filed an estimate of his income under section 18A 2  and of the tax payable by him, and on January 10, 1948, he filed a revised estimate.

facts.text: On January 10, 1948, the assessee filed a revised estimate.

anchor.surface_text: and on January 10, 1948, he filed a revised estimate. An order under section 23B of the Act provisionally assessing the income was made by the Income-tax Officer and pursuant thereto on August 23, 1950, the assessee paid the tax so assessed.

facts.text: An order under section 23B provisionally assessing the income was made by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: An order under section 23B of the Act provisionally assessing the income was made by the Income-tax Officer and pursuant thereto on August 23, 1950, the assessee paid the tax so assessed. Regular assessment of the income was made on March 31, 1953, by the Income-tax Officer

facts.text: On August 23, 1950, the assessee paid the tax pursuant to the provisional assessment under section 23B.

anchor.surface_text: and pursuant thereto on August 23, 1950, the assessee paid the tax so assessed. Regular assessment of the income was made on March 31, 1953, by the Income-tax Officer, and it was found that the tax paid on the basis of the estimate of the assessee was less than eighty per cent of tax determined as a result of the regular assessment.

facts.text: Regular assessment of the income was made on March 31, 1953, by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Regular assessment of the income was made on March 31, 1953, by the Income-tax Officer, and it was found that the tax paid on the basis of the estimate of the assessee was less than eighty per cent of tax determined as a result of the regular assessment. But the Income-tax Officer made numbercharged for interest under sub-section  6  of S. 18-A of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The tax paid on the basis of the assessee's estimate was less than eighty per cent of the tax determined as a result of the regular assessment.

anchor.surface_text: and it was found that the tax paid on the basis of the estimate of the assessee was less than eighty per cent of tax determined as a result of the regular assessment. But the Income-tax Officer made numbercharged for interest under sub-section  6  of S. 18-A of the Income-tax Act. The departmental auditor raised an objection in auditing accounts of C-II Ward that a mistake was companysitted by the Income-tax Officer

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer did not charge interest under sub-section (6) of section 18A.

anchor.surface_text: But the Income-tax Officer made numbercharged for interest under sub-section  6  of S. 18-A of the Income-tax Act. The departmental auditor raised an objection in auditing accounts of C-II Ward that a mistake was companysitted by the Income-tax Officer in failing to charge interest in making the order of assessment against the assessee.

facts.text: The departmental auditor raised an objection that the Income-tax Officer failed to charge interest.

anchor.surface_text: The departmental auditor raised an objection in auditing accounts of C-II Ward that a mistake was companysitted by the Income-tax Officer in failing to charge interest in making the order of assessment against the assessee. On September 21, 1956, the Income-tax Officer served a numberice upon the assessee requiring him to show cause why the mistake in number levying interest be number rectified

facts.text: On September 21, 1956, the Income-tax Officer served a notice upon the assessee to show cause why the mistake in levying interest be rectified under section 18A(6).

anchor.surface_text: On September 21, 1956, the Income-tax Officer served a numberice upon the assessee requiring him to show cause why the mistake in number levying interest be number rectified and why he should number directed to pay penal interest under section 18A 6 . On October 4, 1956, the Income-tax Officer recorded the following order

facts.text: On October 4, 1956, the Income-tax Officer recorded an order rectifying the mistake under section 35 after notice to assessee.

anchor.surface_text: On October 4, 1956, the Income-tax Officer recorded the following order During the internal checking of C-II Ward, the auditor has pointed out a mistake is apparent from record the same is rectified under section 35 after giving due numberice to the assessee. and served a numberice of demand calling upon the assessee to pay Rs. 14,929-10-0 as interest due under section 18A 6  for the period January 1, 1948, to July 22, 1950.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer served notice of demand for Rs. 14,929-10-0 as interest under section 18A(6) for period January 1, 1948 to July 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and served a numberice of demand calling upon the assessee to pay Rs. 14,929-10-0 as interest due under section 18A 6  for the period January 1, 1948, to July 22, 1950. In exercise of his powers under section 33A, by order dated February 1, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer rectifying the original order of assessment and imposing liability to pay interest

facts.text: By order dated February 1, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax confirmed the rectification order under section 33A, modified interest till June 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of his powers under section 33A, by order dated February 1, 1958, the Commissioner of Income-tax companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer rectifying the original order of assessment and imposing liability to pay interest, subject to the modification that interest be paid only till June 13, 1950.

facts.text: The assessee moved the High Court of Bombay by petition under article 226 for writ of certiorari to quash the Commissioner's order under section 33A, ITO's order under section 35, and notice of demand.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then moved the High Court of Judicature at Bombay by a petition under article 226 of the Constitution for issue of a writ of certiorari summoning the record of the case and for an order quashing or setting aside the order passed under section 33A 2  by the Commissioner of Income-tax and the order passed by the Income-tax Officer under section 35 and the numberice of demand pursuant to that order.

facts.text: The High Court of Bombay quashed the orders of the Income-tax Officer and Commissioner following Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay, following its earlier judgment in the case of Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair, IV Income-tax Officer, E Ward Bombay, directed that the orders passed by the Income-tax Officer and by the Commissioner of Income-tax be quashed.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax and Income-tax Officer appealed to Supreme Court with certificate granted by High Court under article 133.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Officer have, with certificate granted by the High Court, appealed to this companyrt.

facts.text: Counsel for assessee raised preliminary objection that appeal was incompetent as writ petition under article 226 is not civil proceeding under article 133.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal companynsel for the assessee raised an objection in limine that the appeal filed by the Commissioner and the Income-tax Officer was incompetent, because the High Court had numberpower under article 133 of the Constitution to certify a proposed appeal against an order in a proceeding companymenced by a petition for the issue of a writ under article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Act 25 of 1953 added proviso to section 18A(6) with retrospective effect from April 1, 1952, allowing ITO to reduce or waive interest in prescribed cases.

anchor.surface_text: But by Act 25 of 1953 which was enacted with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952, the following proviso was added as the fifth provision to S. 18-A  6 . Provided further that in such case and under such circumstances as may be prescribed the Income-tax Officer may reduce or waive the interest payable by the assessee.

facts.text: Central Government prescribed rule 48 in December 1953 for circumstances to reduce/waive interest under section 18A(6).

anchor.surface_text: the discretion was to be exercised were prescribed by the Central Government by rule 48 in December, 1953.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts. There will be one hearing fee in Civil Appeals Nos. 1003 of 1963 and 1004 of 1963.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1004 of 1963 has substantially the same facts as No. 1003 and was also dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1004 of 1963. - The facts in this case are substantially the same as in the companypanion Civil Appeal No. 1003 of 1963, and for reasons set out in the judgment in that case this appeal also fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal 1004, respondents filed estimate under section 18A(2) on September 17, 1947, and made advance payment on September 27, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On September 17, 1947, the respondents field under section 18A 2  an estimate of their income and on September 27, 1947, they made an advance payment of tax on its basis.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal 1004, revised estimate filed on January 10, 1948, further payment on January 17, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On January 10, 1948, they filed a revised estimate in pursuance of which they made a further advance payments towards the tax on January 17, 1948.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal 1004, tax paid on August 23, 1950 pursuant to provisional assessment on July 22, 1950 under section 23B for AY 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: On August 23, 1950 they paid the tax in pursuance of the provisional assessment made on July 22, 1950, under section 23B. All this was with respect to the assessment year 1948-49.

facts.text: Mudholkar J agreed that writ proceeding under article 226 is civil proceeding under article 133.

anchor.surface_text: Mudholkar, J. I agree with my learned brother Shah J. that the expression civil proceedings in article 133 1  of the Constitution cannot be restricted to proceedings which arise out of civil suits or proceedings.

arguments.claim: The appeal is incompetent because the High Court had no power under article 133 to certify an appeal from an order in a writ petition under article 226 as it is not a civil proceeding

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of this appeal counsel for the assessee raised an objection in limine that the appeal filed by the Commissioner and the Income-tax Officer was incompetent, because the High Court had nopower under article 133 of the Constitution to certify a proposed appeal against an order in a proceeding commenced by a petition for the issue of a writ under article 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Writ proceedings under Art 226 enforcing civil rights against tax levy are civil proceedings under Art 133; taxation affects civil rights of taxpayer

arguments.claim: Proceeding under Art 226 is a civil proceeding under Art 133 as it involves assertion of civil rights conferred by statute and relief for breach thereof

anchor.surface_text: The expression civil proceeding in our judgment covers all proceedings in which a party asserts the existence of a civil right conferred by the civil law or by statute, and claims relief for breach thereof. A criminal proceeding on the other hand is ordinarily one in which if carried to its conclusion it may result

arguments.claim: Proceedings relating to revenue or tax are not civil proceedings but fall under 'other proceedings' excluding them from Art 133

arguments.court_reasoning: No warrant to exclude revenue proceedings from civil; tax levy affects civil rights; Art 132 'other proceeding' emphasizes inclusion if constitutional question

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he had decided to waive the amount of interest and in those circumstances he had numberjurisdiction subsequently There is numberdoubt that by making

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority follows HC view of deemed exercise via legal fiction

arguments.claim: Rule 48 deemed retrospective as proviso retrospective

anchor.surface_text: The proviso was itself made retrospective as from April 1, 1952. Rule 48 as soon as it was framed was to be read along with the proviso and as the proviso is retrospective the rule must also be deemed retrospective.

holdings.text: A proceeding under Article 226 of the Constitution challenging levy of tax is a civil proceeding within the meaning of Article 133(1), empowering the High Court to grant certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful review of the provisions of the Constitution, we are of the opinion that there is no ground for restricting the expression civil proceeding only to those proceedings which arise out of civil suits or proceedings which are tried as civil suits, nor is there any rational basis for excluding from its purview proceedings instituted and tried in the High Court in exercise of its jurisdiction under article 226,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Civil proceeding defined broadly to include assertion of civil rights under statute against state action like tax levy; no exclusion for revenue matters; contrasts with criminal; Art 132 'other proceedings' inclusive.

holdings.text: The fifth proviso to section 18A(6) added by Income-tax and Business Profits (Emergency Charges) Amendment Act, 1953 has retrospective operation from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: But by Act 25 of 1953 which was enacted with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952, the following proviso was added as the fifth proviso to S. 18-A(6). Provided further that in such case and under such circumstances as may be prescribed the Income-tax Officer may reduce or waive the interest payable by the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature expressly provided retrospective effect; creates legal fiction vesting discretion as from that date.

holdings.text: Rule 48 of Income-tax Rules prescribing cases and circumstances for exercise of discretion under proviso to section 18A(6) is deemed retrospective from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature has expressly given operation to the fifth proviso to section 18A(6), from April 1, 1952. It is true that the proviso operates only in respect of cases and under circumstances as may be prescribed, but as soon as rules were framed, which effectuate the purposes for which the proviso was enacted, the proviso and the rules became effective retrospectively from April 1, 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules effectuate proviso; since proviso retrospective, rules read with it become retrospective upon framing.

holdings.text: Omission by Income-tax Officer to charge interest under section 18A(6) in regular assessment order dated March 31, 1953 does not constitute mistake apparent from record warranting rectification under section 35, as by retrospective operation of proviso and Rule 48, ITO deemed to possess discretion and omission implies its exercise.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the retrospective amendment in section 18A(6) the order which was made by the Income-tax Officer on the date of assessment and which was plainly inconsistent with the terms of the section as it then stood became one which he was competent to pass in exercise of his power. [...] the case of the assessee did fall within the terms of rule 48(i) and the Income-tax Officer must in law be bound to consider whether he was entitled to reduction or waiver of interest under the fifth proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal fiction deems law extant at assessment; case falls under Rule 48(i); bound to consider waiver; omission deemed conscious exercise barring later rectification as mistake apparent.

holdings.text: The Commissioner of Income-tax committed error of law apparent on record under section 33A by confirming rectification without considering retrospective proviso to section 18A(6) and Rule 48.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was brought before the Commissioner of Income-tax and it is unfortunate that the Commissioner in considering the matter under S. 33-A assumed that the amending Act 25 of 1953 had no retrospective operation and rejected the claim of the assessee [...] In so holding, the Commissioner committed an error of law apparent on the face of the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commissioner ignored express retrospective operation and applicability to facts.

holdings.text: High Court was right in quashing orders of Income-tax Officer under section 35 and Commissioner under section 33A.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in setting aside the order which was passed by the Commissioner without considering the proviso to S. 18-A(6) which was clearly applicable to the case of the assessee and in the light of R. 48 which was enacted in pursuance of that Proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from invalidity of rectification due to deemed waiver.

precedents.citation: Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair, IV Income-tax Officer, E Ward Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Bombay, following its earlier judgment in the case of Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair, IV Income-tax Officer, E Ward Bombay, directed that the orders passed by the Income-tax Officer and by the Commissioner of Income-tax be quashed. Against the order passed by the High Court the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Officer have, with certificate granted by the High Court, appealed to this court.

precedents.case_name: Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair
precedents.cited_proposition: grounds for quashing orders of Income-tax Officer and Commissioner under sections 35 and 33A regarding levy of interest under section 18A(6)

precedents.citation: Rangoon Botatoung Co. Ltd. v. The Collector, Rangoon, 39 Ind App 197 PC

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the enactment of section 54 of the Land Acquisition Act which expressly provides for an appeal to this court subject to the provisions contained in section 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure, from an award, or from any part of the award made by the court is easily appreciated, it regard be had to the character of .the adjudication, which is in the nature of an award in an arbitration see Rangoon Botatoung Co. Ltd. v. The Collector, Rangoon, 39 Ind App 197 PC .

precedents.case_name: Rangoon Botatoung Co. Ltd. v. The Collector, Rangoon
precedents.cited_proposition: character of land acquisition adjudication is in the nature of an award in an arbitration

precedents.citation: T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri appearing on behalf of the assessee contended that this court has laid down in T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem that where power is conferred upon an authority and it is made exercisable in the manner provided by subsidiary legislative, failure top enact such subsidiary legislation will not defeat the power the power will be exercisable without the restrictions which may be, but are not imposed, and therefore once the power of the Income-tax Officer came into being that power became exercisable immediately without restrictions or limitations until the Central Government chose to frame rules defining those restrictions.

precedents.case_name: T. Cajee v. U. Jormanik Siem
precedents.cited_proposition: where power conferred upon authority exercisable by subsidiary legislation, failure to enact does not defeat power; power exercisable without restrictions until rules framed

precedents.citation: M. K. Venkatachalam v, Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: This court in M. K. Venkatachalam v, Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Co. Ltd. held in dealing with the case arising under the second proviso to section 18A 5   which was also inserted by Act 25 of 1953 with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952  that the Income-tax Officer has power under section 35 of the Act to rectify a mistake in the assessment, even though the mistake was the result of a legal fiction arising from the retrospective operations given to the amending Act.

precedents.case_name: M. K. Venkatachalam v. Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Income-tax Officer has power under section 35 to rectify mistake resulting from retrospective amendment creating legal fiction
precedents.cited_holding: power under s.35 to rectify even mistake from retrospective operation

precedents.citation: Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. Nair, IV Income-tax Officer, E Ward, Bombay

anchor.surface_text: After referring to the earlier decision of the High Court in Shantilal Rawji v. M. C. anchor.surface_text: On a careful review of the provisions of the Constitution, we are of the opinion that there is no ground for restricting the expression civil proceeding only to those proceedings which arise out of civil suits or proceedings which are tried as civil suits, nor is there any rational basis for excluding from its purview proceedings instituted and tried in the High Court in exercise of its jurisdiction under article 226,

On a careful review of the provisions of the Constitution, we are of the opinion that there is no ground for restricting the expression civil proceeding only to those proceedings which arise out of civil suits or proceedings which are tried as civil suits, nor is there any rational basis for excluding from its purview proceedings instituted and tried in the High Court in exercise of its jurisdiction under article 226,

anchor.surface_text: But by Act 25 of 1953 which was enacted with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952, the following proviso was added as the fifth proviso to S. 18-A(6). Provided further that in such case and under such circumstances as may be prescribed the Income-tax Officer may reduce or waive the interest payable by the assessee.

But by Act 25 of 1953 which was enacted with retrospective operation from April 1, 1952, the following proviso was added as the fifth proviso to S. 18-A(6). Provided further that in such case and under such circumstances as may be prescribed the Income-tax Officer may reduce or waive the interest payable by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature has expressly given operation to the fifth proviso to section 18A(6), from April 1, 1952. It is true that the proviso operates only in respect of cases and under circumstances as may be prescribed, but as soon as rules were framed, which effectuate the purposes for which the proviso was enacted, the proviso and the rules became effective retrospectively from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was brought before the Commissioner of Income-tax and it is unfortunate that the Commissioner in considering the matter under S. 33-A assumed that the amending Act 25 of 1953 had no retrospective operation and rejected the claim of the assessee [...] In so holding, the Commissioner committed an error of law apparent on the face of the record.

The matter was brought before the Commissioner of Income-tax and it is unfortunate that the Commissioner in considering the matter under S. 33-A assumed that the amending Act 25 of 1953 had no retrospective operation and rejected the claim of the assessee [...] In so holding, the Commissioner committed an error of law apparent on the face of the record.

The High Court was therefore right in setting aside the order which was passed by the Commissioner without considering the proviso to S. 18-A(6) which was clearly applicable to the case of the assessee and in the light of R. 48 which was enacted in pursuance of that Proviso.
